choices.text: Hypokalemia increases neuronal excitability because it causes the neuron to be depolarized.
Hypokalemia increases neuronal excitability because it causes the neuron to be hyperpolarized.
Hypokalemia decreases neuronal excitability because it causes the neuron to be hyperpolarized.
Hypokalemia has no effect on neuronal excitability or membrane potential.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with chronic renal failure presents to the emergency room with muscle weakness and ECG changes suggestive of cardiac arrhythmia. Blood tests reveal significantly low serum potassium levels. During her neurological assessment, you consider the impact of her hypokalemia on neuronal excitability and membrane potential. Based on the physiological effects of hypokalemia on neurons, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypokalemia decreases neuronal excitability because it causes the neuron to be hyperpolarized.

 

Option C: Correct. In hypokalemia, the resting membrane potential becomes more negative (hyperpolarization), which increases the threshold for action potential generation. This makes neurons less excitable, not more.

 

  • The normal serum potassium levels will be around 3.5 to 5 mEq/L (> 8 mEq/L – severe Hyperkalemia)
  • Depending on the variations in the serum potassium levels, the excitation of the neurons will also be variable
  • In case of hypokalemia,(K+ gradient towards outside will be increased- more K+ will move outside) the membrane potential will be reduced and the neuron will be hyperpolarized and not excitable

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Hypokalemia leads to hyperpolarization of the neuron, not depolarization. Hyperpolarization makes neurons less likely to reach the threshold for action potential generation, thus decreasing excitability.

 

Option B: Incorrect. While hypokalemia does cause hyperpolarization, this state actually decreases neuronal excitability, not increases it.

 

Option D: Incorrect. Hypokalemia affects neuronal excitability by hyperpolarizing the neuronal membrane, making it less likely for action potentials to occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To assess the understanding of the effect of serum potassium levels on neuronal excitability and membrane potential.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 91

choices.text: A – Sodium (Na+), B – Potassium (K+)
A – Potassium (K+), B – Sodium (Na+)
A – Sodium (Na+), B – Calcium (Ca2+)
A – Calcium (Ca2+), B – Sodium (Na+)

questions.text: In the context of an action potential, a graph displays two distinct peaks representing ion permeabilities over time in a neuron. With peak A occurring before peak B, identify the ions corresponding to these peaks?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A – Sodium (Na+), B – Potassium (K+)

 

Option A: Correct. During an action potential, sodium (Na+) channels open first, resulting in a rapid increase in sodium permeability, which corresponds to peak A. Subsequently, potassium (K+) channels open, leading to an increase in potassium permeability as the cell repolarizes, which corresponds to peak B.

 

 

Explanations:

 

Option B: Incorrect. Potassium (K+) channels typically open after sodium (Na+) channels during an action potential, so peak A cannot represent potassium.

 

Option C: Incorrect. While calcium (Ca2+) channels are important in some types of action potentials, particularly in cardiac muscle cells, they are not typically represented in the standard neuron action potential graph, which mainly involves sodium and potassium.

 

Option D: Incorrect. Calcium (Ca2+) channels are not the primary ion channels involved in the generation of a standard neuronal action potential; thus, they would not be represented as one of the primary peaks in such a graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the sequence of ion permeability changes during the neuronal action potential.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 95

choices.text: Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
The assertion statement is incorrect, but the reason statement is correct
Both the assertion and the reason statements are incorrect

questions.text:
Assertion: In absolute refractory period, the nerve cannot be stimulated even with a strong stimulus

 

Reason: Majority of the sodium channels are in inactivated state during the early part of the refractory period

 

Identify the correct statement from the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

 

Explanation:

 

  • There are two types of refractory period – absolute and relative
  • Even with a stronger stimulus, the nerve can never be excited during absolute refractory period, whereas stronger stimulus can excite the nerve during relative refractory period
  • Refractory period can be shown as:

 

 

  • During the absolute refractory period, majority of the sodium channels are in inactivated state, hence the nerve can not be excited (early part of the total refractory period)
  • These channels do not open till the membrane returns back to the resting state

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question aims to test the candidate's understanding of the mechanisms underlying the absolute refractory period in neurons, particularly focusing on the role of sodium channel inactivation.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 70

choices.text: The patient is at risk of increased neuronal excitability and seizures.
Hypokalemia may lead to hyperpolarization and peripheral neuropathy.
Reduced extracellular potassium could result in decreased membrane potential and cognitive dysfunction.
The patient may experience enhanced excitability of neurons and an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of gastrointestinal issues is admitted to the hospital with symptoms of muscle cramps, tingling sensations, and cardiac arrhythmias. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia. How might the decreased extracellular potassium concentration affect the patient's neuronal excitability, and what specific neurological and cardiovascular complications could arise due to this electrolyte imbalance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypokalemia may lead to hyperpolarization and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option B: Correct. Hypokalemia increases the potential difference across the neuronal membrane (hyperpolarization), making it more difficult to reach the threshold for action potentials and potentially leading to muscle weakness and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Hypokalemia typically decreases neuronal excitability, not increases it, making it less likely for seizures to occur.

 

Option C: Incorrect. Reduced extracellular potassium does decrease membrane potential; however, cognitive dysfunction is not a direct result, although confusion can occur.

 

Option D: Incorrect. Hypokalemia actually decreases neuronal excitability, but it does increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias due to its effects on heart muscle cells, not neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the pathophysiological consequences of hypokalemia on neuronal and muscle cell excitability, including the risk of peripheral neuropathy and cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Refer: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 26th edition, pg no: 90

choices.text: 1,2,5
1,3,5
2 ,4
2,3,4,5

questions.text:
In the assessment of a patient's neurological status, a clinician observes certain synaptic potentials. Which statement is inconsistent with accurate characterization of synaptic potentials in nerve fibers for this patient?

 

  1. It is also referred to as resting membrane potential
  2. They are the prerequisite for generation of propagated action
    potential
  3. Local potentials can begin from Resting membrane potential & can be both depolarizing and hyperpolarizing.
  4. They are non-propagated
  5. It is a consequence of the passive diffusion of K+ ions from outside to inside of the cell
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1,2,5

 

Option A: Correct. Resting membrane potential is not the same as synaptic potentials – they are local potentials, produced by subthreshold stimulus. Synaptic potentials are indeed prerequisites for the generation of action potentials, but they do not result from passive diffusion of K+ ions from outside to inside of the cell—this describes potassium's role in establishing resting membrane potential, not synaptic potentials. They can be both depolarizing and hyperpolarizing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Incorrect. Statement 3 is consistent with the properties of nerve fibers; Local potentials can begin from RMP & can be both depolarizing and hyperpolarizing.

 

Option C: Incorrect. Statement 2 is inaccurate; but, Statement 4 is accurate; synaptic potentials are usually localized and non-propagated.

 

Option D: Incorrect. Statements 2 and 4 are accurate descriptions of synaptic potentials.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to discern between different types of electrical potentials in nerve fibers and to correct common misconceptions about their properties and functions.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Pg No: 65, 66

choices.text: Hyperpolarization facilitates reaching the threshold value more easily.
Voltage-gated potassium channels closing more slowly leads to a less negative membrane potential.
GABA, an inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitter, exerts its effects by inducing depolarization.
Hyperpolarization inhibits neuronal function because reaching the threshold value from a more negative membrane potential is challenging.

questions.text: A neurologist assesses a patient with fluctuating levels of consciousness. The patient's EEG shows periods of hyperpolarization. Which of the following statements most accurately correlates hyperpolarization with neuronal function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperpolarization inhibits neuronal function because reaching the threshold value from a more negative membrane potential is challenging.

 

Option D: Correct. Hyperpolarization increases the polarity of the neuron's membrane potential, making it more negative and thus more challenging for the neuron to reach the threshold necessary to fire an action potential.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Hyperpolarization moves the membrane potential further away from the threshold, making it more difficult, not easier, to reach the threshold for firing an action potential.

 

Option B: Incorrect. Voltage-gated potassium channels closing more slowly would actually cause the membrane potential to become more negative, not less, due to prolonged potassium efflux.

 

Option C: Incorrect. GABA, as an inhibitory neurotransmitter, typically causes hyperpolarization by increasing the permeability of the membrane to chloride ions or enhancing potassium efflux, not depolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to analyze the impact of membrane potential changes on neuronal excitability, particularly how hyperpolarization affects the ability of neurons to fire action potentials.

 

Refer: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Pg No: 581, 582

choices.text: The patient is at risk of decreased neuronal excitability and seizures.
Hyperkalemia increases the risk of hyperpolarization and motor neuron paralysis.
Elevated extracellular potassium makes neurons more excitable, raising the risk of seizures.
The patient may experience a decrease in membrane potential, leading to cognitive impairment.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with weakness, confusion, and muscle twitching. Laboratory results indicate hyperkalemia. How might the mild to moderately elevated extracellular potassium concentration impact the patient's neuronal excitability, and what potential neurological manifestations and complications should the healthcare team be vigilant for in managing this electrolyte imbalance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevated extracellular potassium makes neurons more excitable, raising the risk of seizures.

 

Option C: Hyperkalemia reduces the gradient between the inside and outside of the neuron, making it easier to reach the threshold potential and potentially leading to seizures due to increased neuronal excitability.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Hyperkalemia typically increases neuronal excitability, not decreases it (Unless it’s a case of severe and prolonged Hyperkalemia), and can lead to muscle weakness or paralysis rather than seizures.

 

Option B: Incorrect. While hyperkalemia can lead to changes in membrane potential, it does not directly cause hyperpolarization; instead, it can decrease the magnitude of the potential difference across the membrane, making neurons more excitable.

 

Option D: Incorrect. While hyperkalemia affects membrane potential, it does not directly lead to cognitive impairment, although confusion can be a secondary effect due to generalized increased neuronal activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective is to understand the effects of hyperkalemia on neuronal excitability and the potential neurological consequences of this electrolyte imbalance.

 

Refer: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 26th edition, pg no: 90

choices.text: Increased extracellular potassium concentration, which would elevate the resting membrane potential closer to the threshold.
Hyperpolarization of the neuron due to an enhanced efflux of potassium ions, increasing the difference between the RMP and the threshold.
Augmentation of the sodium-potassium pump activity, leading to a greater hyperpolarization of the resting membrane potential.
Excessive chloride ion influx, which would stabilize the membrane potential further away from the firing threshold.

questions.text: A medical resident is reviewing the case of a patient who has sustained a severe head injury leading to cerebral edema. The neurosurgeon discusses the risk of neuronal hyperexcitability due to changes in ion distribution. Which of the following factors would decrease the firing level (threshold potential) of a neuron, thus making it more likely to reach a spike potential?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased extracellular potassium concentration, which would elevate the resting membrane potential closer to the threshold.

 

Option A: is correct. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration would reduce the potassium gradient, leading to a less negative resting membrane potential. This would bring the membrane potential closer to the threshold, making the neuron more excitable.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: is incorrect. Hyperpolarization would increase the difference between the RMP and the threshold potential, making it less likely for the neuron to reach the spike potential.

 

Option C: is incorrect. Increasing the activity of the sodium-potassium pump would hyperpolarize the neuron by moving three sodium ions out for every two potassium ions in, moving the RMP further from the threshold, not closer.

 

Option D: is incorrect. Chloride ions typically contribute to inhibitory post-synaptic potentials. An influx would hyperpolarize the cell or keep it at a more negative potential, thus making it less likely to reach the spike potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests the candidate's understanding of the physiological principles governing the resting membrane potential and factors influencing the firing threshold of neurons. It requires the integration of knowledge about ion gradients, membrane potentials, and the effects of changes in ion concentrations on neuronal excitability.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, pg no: 70, 71

choices.text: Point A – Resting membrane potential
Point B – Threshold potential
Point E – Repolarization phase
Point F – After-hyperpolarization phase

questions.text: Given the nerve action potential graph, identify the point where potassium ion (K+) permeability is at its highest.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point E – Repolarization phase

 

Option C: Correct. Point E occurs during the repolarization phase of the action potential. At this point, K+ channels are fully open, allowing for a large efflux of K+ to repolarize the membrane, thereby reflecting the highest K+ permeability.

 

 

Explanations:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Point A indicates the resting membrane potential where K+ permeability is not at its peak but is responsible for maintaining the resting potential.

 

Option B: Incorrect. Point B marks the threshold potential, which is predominantly influenced by Na+ influx, not an increase in K+ permeability.

 

Option D: Incorrect. Point F represents the after-hyperpolarization phase where K+ permeability is still above baseline but is returning to its resting level after having been at its peak during repolarization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The goal is to understand the ionic basis of the action potential phases, particularly the role of potassium ions during repolarization.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 90

choices.text: Hypercalcemia increases membrane excitability.
Hypercalcemia reduces membrane excitability.
Hypercalcemia has no effect on membrane excitability.
Hypercalcemia leads to unpredictable changes in membrane excitability.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is diagnosed with hypercalcemia. The medical team is evaluating how this condition affects the patient's membrane excitability. Which of the following best describes the impact of hypercalcemia on membrane excitability?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia reduces membrane excitability.

 

Option B: Correct. Elevated calcium levels increase the threshold potential via reducing the sodium permeability, making it harder for neurons to reach a firing level and generate an action potentials.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Hypercalcemia does not increase membrane excitability. Instead, it has the opposite effect due to its inhibitory influence on Sodium ion channels and membrane potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect. Hypercalcemia does affect membrane excitability by altering the threshold potential required for action potentials.

 

Option D: Incorrect. The effect of hypercalcemia on membrane excitability is not unpredictable. It consistently leads to a reduction in excitability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to understand how electrolyte imbalances, such as hypercalcemia, affect membrane excitability, crucial for the clinical management of patients with such imbalances.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 91

choices.text: The statement X is true, the statement Y is false
The statement X is false, the statement Y is true
Both the statements X and Y are true
Both the statements X and Y are false

questions.text:
In a specialized clinic for neurological disorders, a neurologist is reviewing the case of a 38-year-old patient presenting with episodic ataxia and intermittent tremors. To elucidate the underlying pathophysiology, the neurologist considers the ion channel dynamics and membrane permeabilities that govern neuronal excitability.

 

Statement X: The neuronal membrane permeability to sodium will be higher at resting conditions

 

Statement Y: More calcium channels will remain open around the resting membrane potential of the neurons

 

Which of the following holds right regarding these two statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both the statements X and Y are false

 

Explanation:

 

  • The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the neurons will be around -70 mV (more negative inside) under physiological conditions
  • This potential will be near to the equilibrium potential for the potassium ions
  • More potassium channels (not calcium channels) will be open than sodium channels at rest, so the membrane permeability to potassium ions (not sodium ions as mentioned in the question) will be greater.
  • Calcium (Ca2+) channels are not typically open around the resting membrane potential; they are more likely to open during depolarization phases, contributing to various processes such as neurotransmitter release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To comprehend the ion channel dynamics at the neuronal resting membrane potential, particularly the roles of sodium and calcium channels, in maintaining neuronal stability and function.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 90

choices.text: They can summate over time and space.
They decrease in amplitude as they travel away from the point of origin.
They always lead to the generation of an action potential.
Their amplitude is proportional to the strength of the stimulus.

questions.text: A neurologist is evaluating a patient with neurological symptoms suggestive of altered neural excitability. To understand the underlying mechanisms, the neurologist focuses on local (electrotonic) potentials and their characteristics. The following question is posed to medical residents, Which of the following statements about local potentials in neurons is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They always lead to the generation of an action potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect, as local potentials do not always lead to action potentials; they must reach a threshold.

 

  • Characteristics of different types of nerve fibers are:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Local potentials can indeed summate, making them important for reaching threshold.

 

Option B: True, as local potentials are decremental and fade with distance.

 

Option D: The amplitude of local potentials is indeed proportional to the stimulus intensity, unlike action potentials.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the properties of local potentials in neurons and how they differ from action potentials.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 94
